questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following parameters is not indicative of reference Indian adult woman?
questions.explanation:
According to the 2020 guidelines of the National Institute of Nutrition, the weight of the reference 
Indian adult woman is 55 kg.

questions.question: Question 2: The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is:
questions.explanation:
The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is 1 kcal/ hour/ kg of body weight. 479 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: What is the likely energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately active 
lifestyle?
questions.explanation:
The energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately active lifestyle is 
around 2500 kcal/day. An adult woman leading a moderately active lifestyle requires 2130 kcal daily and an additional 
350 kcal is needed in pregnancy. Hence, the total requirement for a moderately working pregnant 
woman is 2480 kcal/ day (approximately 2500 kcal/ day).

questions.question:
Question 4: A nutritionist is preparing a meal plan for a healthy 32-year-old man. Which of the following 
principles must she follow?

options.a: Proteins must constitute 15-30% of the daily energy intake
options.b: Fats must constitute 10-15% of the daily energy intake
options.c: Carbohydrate requirement must be met first followed by protein and fat
options.d: The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins

questions.explanation:
The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins. While constructing a balanced diet, nutrient requirements must be calculated in the following 
sequence: • Protein requirements - 10-15% of daily energy intake • Fat requirement - 15-30% of daily energy intake • Carbohydrates - remaining food energy

questions.question: Question 5: What is the daily requirement of high-quality protein for a 40-year-old man weighing 60 kgs?
questions.explanation:
This man requires 50 g/day of high-quality protein. High-quality protein refers to proteins containing all the essential amino acids. According to 
the FAO/WHO 2007 guidelines, the recommended high-quality protein intake for adult men and 
women is 0.83 g/kg/day. This man weighs 60 kgs. Hence he requires around 50 g (0.83*60 = 49.8) 
of high-quality protein per day. Recommended high-quality protein intake by FAO/WHO: However, the mixed Indian diet does not meet the requirement for high-quality protein. Hence, 
the protein requirement in Indian adults (men and women) is 1g/kg/day of mixed Indian diet 
protein according to the ICMR 2010 guidelines. Age

questions.question:
Question 6: A dietary protein-energy percentage of which of the following is the threshold for inadequate 
protein intake?
questions.explanation:
Dietary protein-energy percentage (PE %) < 4% indicates inadequate protein intake. The PE % 
indicates the proportion of total energy in the diet that is derived from proteins. PE % = (Energy from protein / Total energy in the diet) * 100 Some of the food items and their protein-energy percentage are given below: Food 
PE% Fish 
80 20 Cow 
milk Dal 
24 Rice 
8 6 Potat 
o 4 Bana 
na 2 Tapio 
ca

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the best indicator of protein quality?

options.a: Protein digestibility corrected amino acid score

questions.explanation:
Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator for protein quality. DIAAS reflects the digestibility of individual amino acids in the protein. Total protein digestibility 
does not always reflect the digestibility of individual dietary indispensable amino acids. Hence, 
DIAAS has replaced the PDCAAS (protein digestibility corrected amino acid score) as the 
preferred index for the evaluation of protein quality.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following has the highest net protein utilization value?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, meat has the highest net protein utilization (NP˜). The NP˜ values of various food items in descending order are: 481 
Sold by @itachibot • Egg - 100 • Meat - 80 • Milk - 75 • Rice - 65 • Soya - 61 Low NP˜ indicates a high protein requirement. The NP˜ of Indian diets is usually between 50 
and 80.

questions.question:
Question 9: A farmer has been consuming a maize-rich diet for many years. Which of the following would 
be lacking in his diet?
questions.explanation:
His diet would be lacking lysine and tryptophan as maize is deficient in these amino acids. Principal Food

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following has the highest content of essential fatty acids?
questions.explanation:
Safflower oil contains the highest content of essential fatty acids. Linoleic acid is the most important essential fatty acid. Milk is also rich in linoleic acid and oleic acid. % content of linoleic acid Dietary sour

questions.question:
Question 11: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the 
following would you advise him to eat?
questions.explanation:
482 
Sold by @itachibot The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI). GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of 
glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose 
or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity. • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils. • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice. • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and 
syrupy foods.

questions.question: Question 12: The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease (stage 5) should ideally be:
questions.explanation:
The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease should ideally be low volume, 
high calories. Dietary factors may have an effect on the progression of kidney disease and its complications. A 
low-volume feed is preferred in order to avoid: • Sodium and volume overload • Hyperkalemia • Hyperphosphatemia • Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation A high-calorie feed is preferred in order to combat the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting 
seen in ESRD.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not used in the assessment of body fat?
questions.explanation:
Breslow's staging is used for the staging of malignant melanoma, not for the assessment of body 
fat.

questions.question:
Question 14: In the Indian population, individuals with BMI falling between which range are defined as 
overweight?
questions.explanation: In the Indian (Asian) population, a BMI of 23-24.99 is classified as overweight. However, in the global population, a BMI of 25-29.99 is considered overweight.

questions.question: Question 15: What value of BMI is considered as 'lethal' in men?
questions.explanation:
A body mass index (BMI) of 13 or less is considered lethal in men. However, females can survive even at a lower BMI up to 11. 483 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following indicators are used in Waterlow’s classification?
questions.explanation:
Waterlow’s classification makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assess 
the nutritional status of children. HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition. On the other hand, 
WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition. The Gomez classification uses weight for age as an indicator of nutritional status. The 
disadvantage is that it is difficult to determine whether the low weight is due to an acute attack of 
malnutrition or chronic undernutrition. 484 
Sold by @itachibot Micronutrients and Water
